Hefei National Laboratory for Physical Sciences at the Microscale, iChEM, Key Laboratory of Surface and Interface Chemistry and Energy Catalysis of Anhui Higher Education Institutes and Department of Chemical Physics, University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 PR China In this paper, a series of heteropoly acids, (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 (x = 1.3, 1.1, 1.0, 0.88), are prepared, characterized and examined as the catalysts for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA. Under the employed reaction condition, Cs2.23Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits an isobutane conversion of 20% and a MAA selectivity of 51% at 335 °C, giving a MAA yield of 0.68 mmolMAA·h−1·gcatalyst −1. Lattice oxygen mobility and acidity of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts play key roles. A fast migration rate and a moderate release rate of lattice oxygen are beneficial to the selective oxidation of isobutane to MAA. Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits strong acid sites facilitating MAA desorption and surface sites strongly binding MAA, causing MAA polymerization which blocks the active sites and decreases the long-term catalytic activity. These results demonstrate that the optimization of lattice oxygen mobility and surface acidity is an effective strategy to fabricate efficient heteropoly acid catalysts for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Polyoxometalate Keggin-type structure Selective oxidation Structure-activity relation Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methacrylic acid (MAA) is industrially used for esterification to produce methyl methacrylate (MMA), the monomer for poly-(methyl-methacrylate) (PMMA) [1–3]. Currently, large-scale synthesis routes of MAA include acetone cyanohydrin, isobutylene oxidation and ethylene carbonylation, which involve toxic or expensive raw materials or complex multi-step synthesis processes [3,4]. The low-cost and one-step oxidation of isobutane (i-C4H10) to MAA has attracted more and more attention [5,6]. Heteropoly acids exhibit unique characteristics in catalyzing selective oxidation reactions. For example, H3PMo12O40 catalyzes the dehydrogenation reaction of isobutyraldehyde to methacrolein (MAL) [7], in which the aldehyde group remains intact and the C-H bond at the α position is activated, whereas it also catalyzes the selective oxidation of MAL to MAA, in which the reaction occurs at the aldehyde group with other functional groups intact [6,8,9]. Therefore, heteropoly acids with modified H3PMo12O40 Keggin structures have been much examined as the catalysts for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA [9–14]. It is generally accepted that the oxidation of isobutane to MAA catalyzed by modified H3PMo12O40 catalysts follows the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [14–25], in which the lattice oxygen around Mo6+ atoms is abstracted by isobutane, accompanied by the reduction of Mo6+ into Mo5+. Incorporation of vanadium into the secondary framework of the Keggin structure was reported beneficial to the oxidation of isobutane by weakening the Mo6+-O bond energy and facilitating the oxidation of Mo5+ into Mo6+ through the redox reaction of V5++Mo5+→ V4++Mo6+. Transition metals [26–28], such as Fe and Cu, were also reported as an efficient intermediary for the transfer of lattice oxygen in the secondary structure of phosphomolybdic acid to increase the oxidation capacity of the catalyst [16,29–31]. The acidity of heteropoly acid catalysts is another important factor for the oxidation of isobutane. It was reported that the surface acid sites mediate the oxidative dehydrogenation of isobutene [27,32]. Replacing the protons of heteropoly acid catalysts with Cs, Fe or Cu cations is commonly used to modify the surface acidity and consequently the catalytic performance in the oxidation of isobutene [28]. Meanwhile, adding water to the reactants was reported beneficial to the recovery of the surface acidity [33–35]. So far, the reported highest selectivity of MAA and MAL is ∼50% by the oxidation of isobutane with isobutane/oxygen ratios of around 2 [36]. Thus, tuning the lattice oxygen mobility and surface acidity with various additives [37], mostly being V, Cs, Cu and Fe, has been much used to optimize the catalytic performance of heteropoly acid catalysts in the oxidation of isobutene [29,30]. In this paper, we report a new approach to synthesize a series of heteropoly acid catalysts with the fixed relative amounts of V, Cs and Cu additives and varied ratios between V, Cs and Cu to the PMo12O40 unit [28]. Via such an approach, we successfully acquire an active Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 heteropoly acid catalyst that exhibits an isobutane conversion of 20% and MAA selectivity and yield respectively of 51% and 0.68 mmolMAA·h−1·gcatalyst −1 in the oxidation of isobutane with an isobutane/oxygen ratio of 1.0 at 335 °C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis All chemical reagents with analytical grade were used as received. Cs2CO3 was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Cu(NO3)2 and H3PMo12O40·xH2O were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. VOSO4 was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Shanghai) Trading Co., Ltd. Calculated volumes of 0.04 g/mL H3PMo12O40·xH2O aqueous solution were firstly heated to 80 °C to become transparent and clear, to which three 10 mL aqueous solutions containing calculated amounts of Cs2CO3, Cu(NO3)2 and VOSO4 were added dropwise under stirring. The mixed solution was stirred for additional 30 min and then evaporated at 100 °C. The acquired powders were collected and heated in a muffle furnace to 350 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min and kept for 3 h, and then cooled to room temperature to obtain the heteropoly acid catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Catalyst compositions were analyzed by an Optima 7300 DV inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES). Specific surface areas were measured on a Tristar II 3020M automatic specific surface area and pore analyzer. Thermogravimetric-differential thermosgravimetric (TG-DTG) measurements were carried out on a Q5000IR thermogravimetric analyzer. UV–vis spectra were obtained on a SOLID3700 ultraviolet-visible-near-infrared spectrophotometer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Smartlab multi-function rotating target X-ray diffractometer. Transmission infrared spectra were acquired on a Nicolet 8700 Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer. Raman spectra were acquired on a LabRamHR laser Raman spectrometer using 514 nm laser excitation source. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were measured on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer using monochromatic Al Ka (hν = 1486.6 eV) excitation source. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were acquired on a GeminiSEM 500 Schottky field emission scanning electron microscope. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were acquired on a JEM-2100F field emission transmission electron microscope (FETEM). High-angle annular dark field (HAADF) TEM images and element mapping images were obtained on a Talos F200X high-resolution transmission electron microscope. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements was carried out on a DAS-7200 automatic dynamic adsorption instrument. During the NH3-TPD experiments, 100 mg sample was loaded in a quartz tube, pretreated with Ar (30 mL/min) at 200 ℃ for 1 h, and cooled to 100 ℃. The gas stream was then switched to 1% NH3/He (30 mL/min) for 3 h, after which the gas stream was switched back to Ar (30 mL/min) for purge until the baseline was stable. Then the sample was heated to 750 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, during which the NH3 desorption was monitored using an online HIDEN QGA gas analysis system. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) experiments of NH3 adsorption were performed on a Nicolet 6700 Fourier Infrared Spectrometer equipped with a Harrick reactor and a MCT detector. The sample was pretreated at 500 °C in a N2 (20 mL/min) atmosphere and then cooled to 100 °C, during which the spectrum at desired temperatures were taken as the as the background spectrum. Then the gas stream was switched to 1% NH3/He (20 mL/min) for 30 min and switched back to N2 (20 mL/min) to purge the NH3 until the spectrum was stable. Then the sample was heated to 500 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃/min, during which the DRIFTS spectra were measured at desirable temperatures. DRIFTS experiments of MAA adsorption were carried out similarly to those of NH3 adsorption, except that a 270 ppm MAA/N2 gas stream was used to replace the 1% NH3/He gas stream. All DRIFTS spectra were measured with 128 scans at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Pulse adsorption-microcalorimetry measurements of NH3 were carried out on a home-setup consisting of a Setaram Sensys EVO 600 Tian-Calvet microcalorimeter and an Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 automated chemisorption apparatus [38]. A 40 mg sample was placed in the sample quartz tube and degassed in He (flow rate: 50 mL/min) at 200 °C for 60 min, then the sample was cooled to 100 °C, on which pulse adsorption of 0.5 mL 1% NH3/He was carried out. The adsorption amount and accompanying heat flow were quantified by the chemisorption apparatus and microcalorimeter, respectively, from which differential adsorption heats were calculated. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The catalytic oxidation of isobutane was carried out in a home-established fixed-bed flow reactor. 2 g catalyst (20–40 mesh) was loaded in a quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm and heated in the reaction gas of i-C4H10/O2/N2 = 25%/14%/61% (i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.8) or 25%/25%/50% (i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0) at a flow rate of 20 mL/min. The catalyst was heated to desirable temperatures and kept for 2 h to reach a steady state. Then the outlet gas was analyzed by an online Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatography equipped with five types of columns, including PQ 80/100 mesh 3.2 × 2.1 mm × 1.0 m, MS-13X 80/100 mesh 3.2 × 2.1 mm × 3.0 m, Rtx-1 0.32 mm× 5 µm× 5 m, HP-Al2O3/s 0.32 mm × 25 m× 8 µm, Rtx-1 0.32 mm × 60 m× 5 µm. The pipeline between the reactor out of the furnace and the injection port of the chromatograph was kept at 150 °C to ensure the major products such as MAA and MAL in the gas phase. The i-C4H10 conversion and product selectivity were calculated as the following: i-C4H10 conversion% = ([i-C4H10]inlet - [i-C4H10]outlet)/[i-C4H10]inlet × 100% Selectivity% = [i-C4H10]converted to specified product/([i-C4H10]inlet - [i-C4H10]outlet) × 100% The high-boiling point by-products adhered to the quartz reactor inner wall were also dissolved in ethanol and qualitatively analyzed using a LC-LTQ-Orbitrap XL liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS). 3 Results and discussion Totally four catalysts (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 with a fixed Cs:Cu:V= 2.2:0.26:0.38 ratio and varied x values of 1.3, 1.1,1.0 and 0.88 were synthesized, and their compositions were confirmed by ICP-AES (Table S1). Fig. 1a-c shows catalytic performance of various (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts in the oxidation of isobutane with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.8 (i-C4H10/O2/N2 = 25%/14%/61%), a typical value adopted in previous studies [39]. The detailed data is summarized in Table S2. The detected products included MAA, MAL, CH3COOH (AcOH), CO2 and CO. (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 exhibited a high activity in catalyzing the i-C4H10 oxidation but a very low selectivity toward MAA. The i-C4H10 conversion was 13% with an almost full consumption of O2 (Fig. S1) at 300 °C, and the major products were COx while the MAA selectivity was only 4.5%. With the reaction temperature increasing up to 350 °C, the i-C4H10 conversion increased slowly to 15% due to the almost full consumption of O2 while the product selectivity did not vary much. (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 was less active than (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 but much more selective toward MAA production. The i-C4H10 conversion and MAA selectivity were 6.7% and 32% at 300 °C, respectively. As the temperature increased to 320 °C, the i-C4H10 conversion reached 15% with the almost full consumption of O2, while the MAA selectivity did not vary. Then its catalytic performance remained unchanged with the further increase of the reaction temperature up to 350 °C. Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibited the i-C4H10 conversion and MAA selectivity of 6.3% and 53% at 300 °C, respectively. The i-C4H10 conversion kept increasing to 18% as the reaction temperature increased up to 350 °C, while the MAA selectivity did not change at 320 °C but then decreased at elevated temperatures. (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 exhibited the i-C4H10 conversion and MAA selectivity of 6.0% and 51% at 300 °C, respectively. The i-C4H10 conversion kept increasing to 17% as the reaction temperature increased up to 335 °C with the almost full consumption of O2 and then did not change, while the MAA selectivity kept decreasing to 34% at 350 °C. The highest MAA yield was 7.5% achieved over Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 at 335 °C. O2 was not fully consumed at 335 °C during the oxidation of isobutane with a i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.8 catalyzed by the Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst, thus the oxidation of isobutane with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0 (i-C4H10/O2/N2 = 25%/25%/50%) was used to further evaluate the catalytic performance of various (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts (Fig. 1d-f). The detailed data is summarized in Table S3. At the same reaction temperature and over the same catalyst, the i-C4H10 conversion achieved with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0 was higher than with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.8. The highest i-C4H10 conversions for each catalyst were around 25%. Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibited better catalytic performance toward MAA production than other catalysts. Its conversion of i-C4H10 increased from 7.8% to 29% as the reaction temperature increased from 300° to 350°C, while the MAA selectivity increased initially from 52% to 59% and then decreased to 51% and 32%. Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibited the highest MAA yield of 10% at 335 °C (isobutane conversion of 20% and MAA selectivity of 51%), corresponding to 0.68 mmolMAA·h−1·gcatalyst −1. Together with a MAL yield of 1.5%, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibited a MAA+MAL yield of 12% at 335 °C for the oxidation of isobutane with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0, which is much higher than previously-reported data using Keggin-type heteropolyacid catalysts (Table S4). As shown in Fig. 1b and e, the carbon balance for the oxidation of isobutane catalyzed by (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts was approximately 80%, except that catalyzed by Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 at 320 ℃. We did observe the presence of black by-products on the outlet inner wall of quartz reactor (Fig. S2), which were dissolved in ethanol and then analyzed with GC-MS. As shown in Fig. 2a and b, the black by-products mainly showed a peak with a retention time of 9.3–9.6 min in the LC spectrum and a molecular ion peak with m/z of 414.2546 in the MS spectrum. The corresponding molecular formula was deduced as C29H34O2 with an unsaturation degree of 13, whose boiling point is higher than the pipeline temperature (150 °C). The formation of C29H34O2 is likely due to the polymerization of surface intermediates formed during the catalytic reaction [4]. Catalyst stability of Cs2.23Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst in the oxidation of isobutane with a i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0 at 335 ℃ was tested (Fig. 2c). The catalyst was stable in the initial five hours, but then the i-C4H10 conversion decreased from around 19% to around 9% and then did not vary much while the MAA selectivity remained stably around 55%. Structures of various as-synthesized and used catalysts were characterized. BET surface areas of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40, (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalysts were measured as 6.3, 4.0, 8.0 and 3.6 m2/g, respectively. TG curves (Fig. S3) show that as-synthesized (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts undergo obvious weight loss processes above 600 °C. Their stability enhances with the Cs amount, consistent with previous reports [40]. In the XRD patterns ( Fig. 3A), all catalysts showed strong diffraction peaks arising from the (110), (211), (222), (400) and (332) crystal planes of Keggin type heteropoly compounds, consistent with those with a stable cubic secondary structure [28]. In the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 3B), four characteristic peaks of the Keggin structure appeared at 1062, 968, 867 and 795 cm−1 for all catalysts, corresponding to the P–O stretch vibration, M=Ot peripheral metal atoms–terminal oxygen stretch vibration, Mo–Ob–Mo inter-octahedral bridges stretch vibration and Mo–Ob–Mo intra-octahedral bridges stretch vibration, respectively [1]. The observed vibrational features in the FT-IR spectra and diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns are characteristics of the Keggin structural framework (primary structure) and secondary structure of heteropolyacid, respectively (Fig. S4). Thus, our (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts synthesized by adding Cs, Cu, and V to H3PMo12O40 well maintain the primary and secondary Keggin structures, which also keep stable in the catalytic oxidation of isobutane. In the Raman spectra (Fig. 3C), the observed peaks at 228, 238 and 258 cm−1 were attributed to the deformation vibration features of the MoO (end oxygen) and whole Keggin structure [41], the observed peaks at 605, 878 and 961 cm−1 were attributed to the stretch vibration features of Mo-Oc-Mo, Mo-Ob-Mo and P-O, respectively, and the observed peaks at 973 and 990 cm−1 arose from the stretch vibration features of MoOd [11]. All these vibrational features belong to the typical vibration features of the Keggin structure [28] . It can be seen that the peak intensities of used catalysts were much weaker than of corresponding as-synthesized catalysts, which can be related to the consumption of lattice oxygen in the Keggin structure during the catalytic oxidation of isobutane. The used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40, (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.2PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalysts exhibited the vibrational peaks with similar intensities after the oxidation of isobutane with i-C4H10:O2 ratios of 1.8 and 1.0, suggesting that the recovery of surface lattice oxygen did not vary much with the gas-phase oxygen concentration; however, the used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst after the oxidation of isobutane with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0 exhibited much stronger vibrational features than after with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.8, suggesting a faster recovery of surface lattice oxygen. These observations indicate that the Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst is more able to activate gas-phase molecular oxygen into surface lattice oxygen than other (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts. As shown in SEM images ( Fig. 4 and Fig. S5), all as synthesized catalysts consisted of spherical nanoparticles, which remained after the catalytic activity evaluations. Elemental mapping images of Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 (Fig. S6) demonstrated a uniform distribution of all elements within the catalyst nanoparticle. Fig. 5 and Figs. S7-S9 show O 1s, Mo 3d and V 2p3/2 XPS spectra of as-synthesized and used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts. For the as-synthesized catalysts, features of lattice oxygen (Olattice) and adsorbed oxygen (Oads) species with an O 1s binding energy respectively at 531.1 and 532.2 eV, Mo6+ species with a Mo 3d5/2 binding energy at 233.3 eV, and V5+ and V4+ species with a V 2p3/2 binding energy respectively at 517.9 and 516.9 eV appear in the O 1s, Mo 3d, and V 2p3/2 XPS spectra, respectively [28,36]. After the oxidation of isobutane with i-C4H10:O2 ratios of either 1.8 or and 1.0, features of Olattice and Oads species, and V5+ and V4+ species still exist, while in addition to the dominant feature of Mo6+ species, a minor feature of Mo5+ species with a Mo 3d5/2 binding energy at 231.8 eV emerges. The O 1s, Mo 3d and V 2p3/2 XPS spectra were peak-fitted (Figs. S10-S12) and the acquired results were summarized in Table S5. Fig. 6 compares Oads/(Olattice+Oads)%, Mo6+/(Mo6++Mo5+)% and V5+/(V5++V4+)% of as-synthesized and used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts. Among the as-synthesized catalysts, (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 exhibits the highest Oads/(Olattice+Oads) ratio, while among the used catalysts in the oxidation of isobutane with i-C4H10:O2 ratios of either 1.8 or 1.0, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits the highest Oads/(Olattice+Oads) ratios. The adsorbed oxygen species was observed to easily convert to the lattice oxygen species [36]. The oxidation of isobutane over heteropoly acids follows a Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [15,16], in which the lattice oxygen species surrounding the Mo6+ cations on the catalyst surface is abstracted by isobutene [16]. Thus, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits higher capacity than other catalysts to replenish the consumed lattice oxygen species during the oxidation of isobutane. This is also supported by the changes of Mo oxidation states in various catalysts. All as-synthesized (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts only contain the Mo6+ species. After the oxidation of isobutane, the Mo5+ species emerges in all used catalysts due to the consumptions of the lattice oxygen species surrounding the Mo6+ cations. It can be seen that the Mo5+ ratios in used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 are smaller than in other used catalysts, supporting higher capacity of Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 to replenish the consumed lattice oxygen species. Although the used V precursor for catalyst preparations only contains the V4+ species, all as-synthesized (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts contain both V4+ and V5+ species and the V5+ ratio increases as the x value decreases. After the reaction with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.8, the V5+ ratio in the used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.2PMo12O40 catalysts increases slightly, whereas the V5+ ratio in the used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalysts decreases. Among the Olattice and Oads species, the Olattice species is more capable of oxidizing the metal cations than the Oads species. Thus, the V 2p3/2 XPS results suggest that the (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 catalysts are active in activating O2 into the Olattice species under the isobutane oxidation reaction conditions, resulting more V5+ species in the used catalysts than in the corresponding as-synthesized catalysts, whereas the Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalysts are less active, resulting less V5+ species in the used catalysts than in the corresponding as-synthesized catalysts. Upon the decrease of the i-C4H10:O2 ratio from 1.8 to 1.0 and consequently the increase of O2 concentration and i-C4H10 conversions, the V5+ ratio in the used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 catalysts keeps increasing, and the V5+ ratio in the used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst keeps decreasing, but the V5+ ratio in the used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalyst increases greatly. Meanwhile, the Mo6+ ratio slightly decreases in the used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 catalyst but increases in the used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalysts. In the MvK mechanism of the oxidation of isobutane over heteropoly acids [15,16], the Olattice species surrounding the Mo6+ cations on the catalyst surface is abstracted by isobutene and the resulting surface oxygen vacancies is replenished mainly by indirect migration of neighboring Olattice species and minorly by direct O2 activation at the surface oxygen vacancy sites. The increase of V5+ ratio and decrease of Mo6+ ratio of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 catalyst suggest a strong O2 activation into Olattice at the V sites but a migration rate of Olattice from the V sites to the Mo sites not fast enough to replenish all consumed Olattice species at the Mo sites. The increase of both V5+ and Mo6+ ratios of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 catalyst suggest a strong O2 activation into Olattice at the V sites and a migration rate of Olattice from the V sites to the Mo sites fast enough to replenish all consumed Olattice species at the Mo sites. The decrease of V5+ ratio and the increase of Mo6+ ratio of Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst suggest a weak O2 activation into Olattice at the V sites and a migration rate of Olattice from the V sites to the Mo sites fast enough to replenish all consumed Olattice species at the Mo sites. Although exhibiting a weak O2 activation into Olattice at the V sites and a migration rate of Olattice from the V sites to the Mo sites fast enough to replenish all consumed Olattice species at the Mo sites, the low V content and relatively high O2 pressure with an i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0 result in the increase of both V5+ and Mo6+ ratios of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 catalyst. These XPS results demonstrate that an appropriate release rate of Olattice species, a high activity to activate O2 to Oads species, an appropriate activity to convert Oads species into Olattice species and a fast migration rate of Olattice species of Cs2.23Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst under the reaction conditions enables it to supply active Olattice species for the oxidation of isobutane in a limited way and facilely replenish the consumed Olattice species, beneficial for actively and selectively catalyzing the oxidation of isobutane to MAA, while a fast release rate of Olattice species, a high activity to activate O2 to Olattice species and a fast migration rate of Olattice species of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 catalyst under the reaction conditions lead to high i-C4H10 conversion and CO2 selectivity. Fig. 7A shows UV-Vis spectra of various as-synthesized and used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts. The reflectivity of UV-Vis spectra reflects the overall symmetry of the keggin structure of heteropoly acids, such as the symmetry of the MoO6 structure; meanwhile, the features between 210 and 230 nm and 500–600 nm in the UV–vis spectra correspond to the O2-→Mo6+ electron transfer in the heteropoly acid keggin structure [42], in which the longer the wavelength，the weaker the Mo-O bond energy [28]. As shown in Fig. 7B, the used catalysts exhibit weaker reflectivity than corresponding as-synthesized catalysts, suggesting poorer overall symmetry of the keggin structure of used catalysts, which can be associated with the consumption of lattice oxygen in the MoO6 structure during the isobutane oxidation. Among the used catalysts, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 gives slightly stronger reflectivity, indicating better overall symmetry of the keggin structure. This suggests that Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits a higher capacity of to replenish the consumed lattice oxygen species than other catalysts, consistent with the above XPS results. As shown in Fig. 7C, the peak positions of as-synthesized and used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 catalysts are higher than those of other as-synthesized and used (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts, suggesting its weaker Mo-O bond energy, consistent with its higher catalytic activity and CO2 selectivity. Meanwhile, the peak position of as-synthesized (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts are higher corresponding used catalysts, which can be related to the consumption of lattice oxygen species in used catalysts, resulting in enhanced Mo-O bond energy. Fig. 8A shows NH3-TPD following NH3 adsorption on various as-synthesized catalysts at 100 °C. Two NH3 desorption peaks can be identified, one peak is between 180 and 230 ℃ and the other is between 375 and 560 ℃, which are tentatively assigned to NH3 adsorbed at weak and strong acid sites, respectively. (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 exhibits a larger NH3 desorption peak from the weak acid sites than from the strong acid sites, while (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 exhibit larger NH3 desorption peaks from the strong acid sites. The NH3 desorption peaks increase from (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 to (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 and Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 but then decreases to and (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40, meanwhile, Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits the largest NH3 desorption peak from the strong acid sites. Fig. 8B shows the measured differential NH3 adsorption heats following NH3 adsorption on various as-synthesized catalysts at 100 °C. The initial NH3 adsorption heat follows an order of Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 > (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 ≈ (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 > (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40, while the total NH3 adsorption amount follows an order of Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 > (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.1PMo12O40 > (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)0.88PMo12O40 > (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40. These results demonstrate that Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 has the strongest acid sites and the largest amount of total acid sites while (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 exhibits the weakest acid sites and the smallest amount of total acid sites, consistent with the NH3-TPD results. NH3 adsorption on as-synthesized (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 and Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 at 100 °C was further studied using in situ DRIFTS spectra ( Fig. 9). NH3 adsorption at 100 °C gives vibrational features at 1610∼1633/3310∼3324 cm−1 that can be assigned to NH3 adsorbed at the Lewis acid sites and at 1407, 1430∼1460, 1672∼1678, 2765∼2817, 2985 and 3158 cm−1 that can be assigned to NH3 adsorbed at various Brønsted acid sites [43–45]. Upon subsequent heating, it can be seen that the vibrational features at 1407, 1430∼1460 and 1672∼1678 cm−1 vary simultaneously with those at 3158, 2765∼2817 and 2985 cm−1. Thus, three types of Brønsted acid sites exist, at which adsorbed NH3 gives vibrational features at 1407/3158, 1430∼1460/2765∼2817 and 1672∼1678/2985 cm−1. The features at 1430∼1460/2765∼2817 cm−1 disappear firstly, followed by those at 1672∼1678/2985 cm−1 and 1610∼1633/3310∼3324 cm−1, and finally by those at 1407/3158 cm−1. Thus, the features at 1430∼1460/2765∼2817 cm−1 seem to arise from NH3 adsorbed at the weak acid sites, the features at 1672∼1678/2985 cm−1 and 1610∼1633/3310∼3324 cm−1 from the medium acid sites, and the features at 1407/3158 cm−1 strong acid sites. The in situ DRIFTS results show that Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits a much higher density of strong acid sites than (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40, consistent with NH3-TPD and differential NH3 adsorption heat results. It was previously reported that a strong acidity of the catalyst for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA facilitates the desorption of MAA from the catalyst surface [8,11,46]. Thus, the strong acidity of Cs2.23Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 is responsible for the high MAA selectivity. MAA adsorption on as-synthesized (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 and Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 at 100 °C was also studied using in situ DRIFTS spectra ( Fig. 10). Following adsorption on (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 at 100 °C, four vibrational features were observed at 3490, 3370, 2964 and 1630 cm−1. The features at 2964 and 1630 cm−1 can be assigned to the =C-H and CC vibrations of adsorbed MAA [47,48], while the features at 3490 and 3370 cm−1 can be assigned to O-H vibration of adsorbed MAA, suggesting the formation of two types of adsorbed MAA species. Upon subsequent heating, the MAA adsorbed species with the O-H vibration at 3370 cm−1 firstly desorbs from the surface, followed by the MAA adsorbed species with the O-H vibration at 3490 cm−1. All adsorbed MAA species desorb from (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 after heating at 400 °C. MAA adsorption on Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 gives stronger CC and O-H vibrational features than on (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40, but a weaker =C-H vibrational feature; meanwhile, the CC vibrational feature is weaker than the O-H vibrational feature for MAA adsorption on Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 but is stronger on (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40. Upon subsequent heating, the MAA adsorbed species with the O-H vibration at 3200 cm−1 firstly desorbs from the surface, followed by the MAA adsorbed species with the O-H vibration at 3444 cm−1. All adsorbed MAA species desorb from Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 after heating at 450 °C. These results demonstrate that MAA adsorbs more strongly on Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 than on (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)1.3PMo12O40 and minor dissociative adsorption likely occurs on Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40. Therefore, although Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits strong acidity beneficial for MAA desorption, it has surface sites capable of strongly binding MAA, at which the polymerization of surface intermediates likely occurs to form C29H34O2, as observed in the catalytic reaction. The used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst after the oxidation of isobutane with a i-C4H10:O2 ratio of 1.0 at 335 °C for 100 h was characterized in detail. Its XRD patterns (Fig. S13) are similar to those of as-synthesized catalyst. SEM images and elemental mapping images of used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst (Figs. S14 and S15) show that the catalyst sintered into irregular shapes, but still exhibited a uniform elemental distribution. TG-DSC curves of as-synthesized and used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalysts (Fig. S16) show that the used catalyst exhibits an exothermic peak between 400 and 600 °C corresponding to the combustion process of carbon deposits on the catalyst surface, but no obvious weight loss was observed. This suggests that the carbon balance loss is predominantly due to the formation of high boiling point by-products on the outlet inner wall of quartz reactor instead of the carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. This also explains why the initial decrease of the i-C4H10 conversion does not deactivate the Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst. As shown in Fig. S17, the C 1s and O 1s XPS spectra of used Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst also suggest the presence of carbon deposition on the surface, while the Mo 3d and V 2p3/2 XPS spectra show the Mo6+/Mo5+ and V5+/V4+ signals, respectively. 4 Conclusions Via a study of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 (x = 1.3, 1.1, 1.0, 0.88) heteropoly acid catalysts, we have successfully identified Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 as an active and selective catalyst for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA, which exhibits an isobutane conversion of 20% and a MAA selectivity of 51% at 335 °C, giving a MAA yield of 0.68 mmolMAA·h−1·gcatalyst −1. The roles of lattice oxygen mobility and acidity of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts were demonstrated. A fast migration rate and a moderate release rate of lattice oxygen are beneficial to the selective oxidation of isobutane to MAA. Meanwhile, a strong acidity is beneficial for the MAA desorption. However, surface sites strongly binding MAA are present on the Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 catalyst, causing MAA polymerization into high-boiling point by-products which eventually blocks the active sites and decreases the long-term catalytic activity. Presently, MAA can be produced indirectly from isobutane, including isobutane dehydrogenation to isobutene (isobutane conversion: 40.59%; isobutene selectivity: 90.60%) [49], selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein (isobutene conversion: 95.2%; MAL selectivity: 92.2%) [50] and selective oxidation of methacrolein to methacrylic acid (MAL conversion: 82.0%; MAA selectivity: 83.4%) [51], whose overall performance is better than that of direct selective oxidation of isobutane to methacrylic acid. Future studies of heteropoly acid catalysts for the selective oxidation of isobutane to MAA will be devoted, on one hand, to increasing the intrinsic catalytic activity via simultaneous optimizations of migration and release rates of lattice oxygen for efficiently catalyzing the selective oxidation of isobutane to MAA and surface acidity for promoting the desorption of adsorbed MAA, on the other hand, to increasing the surface area of heteropoly acid catalysts with high intrinsic catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, a series of heteropoly acids, (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 (x = 1.3, 1.1, 1.0, 0.88), are prepared, characterized and examined as the catalysts for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA. Under the employed reaction condition, Cs2.23Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits an isobutane conversion of 20% and a MAA selectivity of 51% at 335 °C, giving a MAA yield of 0.68 mmolMAA·h−1·gcatalyst −1. Lattice oxygen mobility and acidity of (Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38)xPMo12O40 catalysts play key roles. A fast migration rate and a moderate release rate of lattice oxygen are beneficial to the selective oxidation of isobutane to MAA. Cs2.2Cu0.26V0.38PMo12O40 exhibits strong acid sites facilitating MAA desorption and surface sites strongly binding MAA, causing MAA polymerization which blocks the active sites and decreases the long-term catalytic activity. These results demonstrate that the optimization of lattice oxygen mobility and surface acidity is an effective strategy to fabricate efficient heteropoly acid catalysts for the oxidation of isobutane to MAA.
coredata.dc:title: Optimizing lattice oxygen mobility and acidity of heteropoly acid catalysts for oxidation of isobutane to methacrylic acid
